name: Kavuni Arisi Puttu – Black Rice Steamed Cake
preparation: Step 1:Wash and soak black rice in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.

Step 2:
 Drain the water and grind the soaked rice into a coarse batter.

Step 3:
 Add grated jaggery to the batter and mix well until it dissolves completely.

Step 4:
 Grate fresh coconut and add it to the batter along with crushed cardamom for flavor.

Step 5:
 Prepare a steamer and grease the puttu mold with coconut oil to prevent sticking.

Step 6:
 Fill the mold with the batter, leaving some space at the top for expansion.

Step 7:
 Steam the batter in the puttu mold for 15-20 minutes on medium heat.

Step 8:
 Check if the puttu is cooked by inserting a toothpick; it should come out clean.

Step 9:
Remove the mold from the steamer and let it cool for 5 minutes.

Step 10:
 Gently unmold the puttu and serve warm with a side of coconut milk or banana.

name: Thinai (Foxtail Millet) Dosai – Crispy Dosa
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak foxtail millet, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds separately for 4-6 hours.
Step 2: Grind the soaked ingredients into a smooth batter, adding water as needed.
Step 3: Mix the batter thoroughly, add salt, and let it ferment overnight in a warm place.
Step 4: Heat a dosa tawa and grease it lightly with oil.
Step 5: Pour a ladleful of batter onto the tawa and spread it in a circular motion to form a thin dosa.
Step 6: Drizzle oil around the edges and cook on medium heat until the dosa turns golden brown.
Step 7: Flip the dosa and cook the other side for 1-2 minutes.
Step 8: Fold the dosa and serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.
Step 9: Repeat the process for the remaining batter.
Step 10: Store leftover batter in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.

name: Kambu Koozh – Pearl Millet Porridge
preparation: Step 1: Mix pearl millet flour with water to form a smooth paste without lumps.
Step 2: Boil water in a pot and slowly add the millet paste, stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Step 3: Cook the mixture on low heat until it thickens into a porridge-like consistency.
Step 4: Remove from heat and let it cool to room temperature.
Step 5: Add buttermilk to the cooled porridge and mix well.
Step 6: Finely chop onions, green chilies, and curry leaves for seasoning.
Step 7: Heat oil in a pan and sauté the chopped ingredients until golden brown.
Step 8: Add the seasoning to the porridge and mix well.
Step 9: Serve chilled or at room temperature as a refreshing breakfast.
Step 10: Optionally, garnish with coriander leaves or grated coconut.

name: Vazhaipoo Adai – Banana Flower Pancake
preparation: Step 1: Clean and finely chop the banana flower, removing the florets and hard parts.
Step 2: Wash and soak rice and urad dal separately for 4-6 hours.
Step 3: Grind the soaked rice and dal into a coarse batter.
Step 4: Add chopped banana flower, red chili, cumin seeds, asafoetida, and salt to the batter.
Step 5: Mix well to ensure even distribution of ingredients.
Step 6: Heat a tawa and grease it lightly with oil.
Step 7: Pour a ladleful of batter onto the tawa and spread it into a thick pancake.
Step 8: Cook on medium heat until both sides are golden brown and crispy.
Step 9: Serve hot with coconut chutney or tomato chutney.
Step 10: Repeat the process for the remaining batter.

name: Murungai Keerai Dosa – Drumstick Leaves-Infused Dosa
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak idli rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds separately for 4-6 hours.
Step 2: Grind the soaked ingredients into a smooth batter, adding water as needed.
Step 3: Allow the batter to ferment overnight in a warm place.
Step 4: Clean and finely chop drumstick leaves, removing any tough stems.
Step 5: Add the chopped drumstick leaves and salt to the batter, mixing well.
Step 6: Heat a dosa tawa on medium heat and lightly grease it with oil.
Step 7: Pour a ladle of batter onto the tawa and spread it in a circular motion to make a thin dosa.
Step 8: Drizzle a little oil around the edges and cook for 2-3 minutes until golden brown.
Step 9: Flip and cook the other side for another 1-2 minutes if needed.
Step 10: Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.
Step 11: Store leftover batter in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.

name: Karuppu Kavuni Arisi Pongal – Black Rice Sweet Pongal
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak black rice in water for at least 4 hours.
Step 2: Cook the soaked rice in a pressure cooker with milk and water until soft.
Step 3: In a separate pan, melt jaggery with a little water to form a syrup.
Step 4: Strain the jaggery syrup to remove impurities and add it to the cooked rice.
Step 5: Mix well and cook on low heat until the mixture thickens.
Step 6: Heat ghee in a small pan and roast cashews and raisins until golden.
Step 7: Add crushed cardamom and the roasted nuts to the pongal, mixing well.
Step 8: Cook for another 2-3 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 9: Serve warm as a sweet and nutritious breakfast.
Step 10: Store leftovers in an airtight container for up to 2 days.

name: Thoothuvalai Dosai – Herbal Dosa
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds separately for 4-6 hours.
Step 2: Clean and grind thoothuvalai leaves into a fine paste.
Step 3: Grind the soaked ingredients into a smooth batter, adding water as needed.
Step 4: Mix the thoothuvalai paste and salt into the batter, ensuring even distribution.
Step 5: Allow the batter to ferment overnight in a warm place.
Step 6: Heat a dosa tawa and grease it lightly with oil.
Step 7: Pour a ladleful of batter onto the tawa and spread it into a thin dosa.
Step 8: Drizzle oil around the edges and cook until golden brown on both sides.
Step 9: Serve hot with coconut chutney or tomato chutney.
Step 10: Store leftover batter in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.

name: Ragi Sevai – Finger Millet String Hoppers
preparation: Step 1: Mix ragi flour and rice flour in a bowl, adding salt to taste.
Step 2: Boil water in a pot and add it to the flour mixture, stirring continuously.
Step 3: Knead the mixture into a smooth dough while it is still warm.
Step 4: Fill the dough into a sevai press or idiyappam maker.
Step 5: Press the dough into thin strands onto idli plates or a steamer tray.
Step 6: Steam the sevai for 10-12 minutes on medium heat.
Step 7: Remove from the steamer and let it cool for 2-3 minutes.
Step 8: Gently separate the strands using a fork or your fingers.
Step 9: Serve hot with coconut chutney, sambar, or any curry of your choice.
Step 10: Store leftovers in an airtight container for up to 2 days.

name: Sweet Karupatti Dosai – Palm Jaggery Dosa
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak rice and urad dal separately for 4-6 hours.
Step 2: Grind the soaked ingredients into a smooth batter, adding water as needed.
Step 3: Allow the batter to ferment overnight in a warm place.
Step 4: Grate palm jaggery and dissolve it in a little warm water.
Step 5: Strain the jaggery syrup to remove impurities and add it to the batter.
Step 6: Add crushed cardamom and mix well to incorporate the flavors.
Step 7: Heat a dosa tawa and grease it lightly with ghee.
Step 8: Pour a ladleful of batter onto the tawa and spread it into a thin dosa.
Step 9: Cook on medium heat until both sides are golden brown.
Step 10: Serve hot with a dollop of ghee or coconut chutney.

name: Vallarai Keerai Chappathi – Brahmi Leaves-Infused Chapati
preparation: Step 1: Clean and finely chop Brahmi leaves, removing any tough stems.
Step 2: Mix the chopped leaves with whole wheat flour and salt in a bowl.
Step 3: Add water gradually and knead into a smooth dough.
Step 4: Divide the dough into small balls and roll them into thin chapatis.
Step 5: Heat a tawa and cook each chapati on medium heat.
Step 6: Flip the chapati and drizzle a little oil around the edges.
Step 7: Cook until both sides are golden brown and slightly crispy.
Step 8: Serve hot with curd, pickle, or any side dish of your choice.
Step 9: Repeat the process for the remaining dough.
Step 10: Store leftover chapatis in an airtight container for up to 2 days.

name: Kothamalli Sevai – Coriander-Flavored Rice Noodles
preparation: Step 1: Blend fresh coriander and green chili into a smooth paste with a little water.
Step 2: Mix rice flour with the coriander paste and salt in a bowl.
Step 3: Boil water and add it to the flour mixture, stirring continuously.
Step 4: Knead the mixture into a smooth dough while it is still warm.
Step 5: Fill the dough into a sevai press or idiyappam maker.
Step 6: Press the dough into thin strands onto idli plates or a steamer tray.
Step 7: Steam the sevai for 10-12 minutes on medium heat.
Step 8: Remove from the steamer and let it cool for 2-3 minutes.
Step 9: Gently separate the strands using a fork or your fingers.
Step 10: Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Mushroom Biryani
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Cook the rice until 70% done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and sauté sliced onions until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy.
Step 4: Add sliced mushrooms and cook until they release moisture and soften.
Step 5: Add yogurt, turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well and cook for 5 minutes.
Step 6: Layer the partially cooked rice over the mushroom mixture. Sprinkle mint and coriander leaves on top.
Step 7: Cover the pan with a tight lid and cook on low heat for 15-20 minutes (dum cooking).
Step 8: Gently mix the biryani before serving. Serve hot with raita or salan.

name: Veg Biryani
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Cook the rice until 70% done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and sauté sliced onions until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy.
Step 4: Add mixed vegetables and cook for 5-7 minutes until slightly tender.
Step 5: Add yogurt, turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well and cook for 5 minutes.
Step 6: Layer the partially cooked rice over the vegetable mixture. Sprinkle mint and coriander leaves on top.
Step 7: Cover the pan with a tight lid and cook on low heat for 15-20 minutes (dum cooking).
Step 8: Gently mix the biryani before serving. Serve hot with raita or salan.

name: Gobi Rice
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Cook the rice until fully done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and sauté sliced onions until translucent. Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies, and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add cauliflower florets and cook until they are slightly tender and golden.
Step 4: Add turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Step 5: Add the cooked rice to the pan and gently mix to combine with the cauliflower mixture.
Step 6: Cook on low heat for 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with raita or pickle.

name: Parotta
preparation: Step 1: In a mixing bowl, combine maida, salt, sugar, and water to form a soft dough.
Step 2: Knead the dough well for 10-15 minutes until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Step 3: Divide the dough into small balls and coat them with oil. Let them rest for 2 hours.
Step 4: Flatten each ball into a thin circle using your hands or a rolling pin.
Step 5: Fold the flattened dough into layers to create a flaky texture.
Step 6: Roll the layered dough into a spiral shape and flatten it again into a circle.
Step 7: Cook the parotta on a hot tawa with oil until both sides are golden brown and crispy.
Step 8: Serve hot with veg kurma or salna.

name: Veg Fried Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook basmati rice until fully done, cool it, and set aside.
Step 2: Heat oil in a wok or pan and sauté finely chopped garlic until fragrant.
Step 3: Add sliced onions and cook until translucent.
Step 4: Add mixed vegetables and stir-fry on high heat for 3-4 minutes.
Step 5: Add soy sauce, vinegar, salt, and pepper. Mix well.
Step 6: Add the cooked rice and toss gently to combine with the vegetables.
Step 7: Garnish with chopped spring onions.
Step 8: Serve hot with manchurian or chili sauce.

name: Paneer Biryani
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Cook the rice until 70% done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and sauté sliced onions until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy.
Step 4: Add cubed paneer and cook for 2-3 minutes until lightly browned.
Step 5: Add yogurt, turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well and cook for 5 minutes.
Step 6: Layer the partially cooked rice over the paneer mixture. Sprinkle mint and coriander leaves on top.
Step 7: Cover the pan with a tight lid and cook on low heat for 15-20 minutes (dum cooking).
Step 8: Gently mix the biryani before serving. Serve hot with raita or salan.

name: Tomato Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook basmati rice until fully done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and sauté sliced onions until translucent. Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies, and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy.
Step 4: Add turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Step 5: Add the cooked rice to the pan and gently mix to combine with the tomato mixture.
Step 6: Cook on low heat for 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with raita or papad.

name: Lemon Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook basmati rice until fully done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter.
Step 3: Add curry leaves, green chilies, and peanuts. Sauté until peanuts turn golden.
Step 4: Add turmeric powder and mix well.
Step 5: Add the cooked rice and gently mix to combine with the tempering.
Step 6: Squeeze fresh lemon juice over the rice and mix well.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with pickle or papad.

name: Coconut Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook basmati rice until fully done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter.
Step 3: Add curry leaves, green chilies, and cashews. Sauté until cashews turn golden.
Step 4: Add grated fresh coconut and sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Step 5: Add the cooked rice and gently mix to combine with the coconut mixture.
Step 6: Cook on low heat for 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with raita or pickle.

name: Sambar Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook rice and toor dal together until soft and set aside.
Step 2: Soak tamarind in water and extract the juice.
Step 3: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter.
Step 4: Add curry leaves and mixed vegetables. Sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Step 5: Add tamarind juice, sambar powder, and salt. Cook until vegetables are tender.
Step 6: Add the cooked rice and dal mixture to the sambar and mix well.
Step 7: Cook on low heat for 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 8: Serve hot with papad or pickle.

name: Curd Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook rice until soft and set aside to cool.
Step 2: Mix curd with the cooled rice and add salt to taste.
Step 3: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter.
Step 4: Add curry leaves, green chilies, and grated ginger. Sauté for 1-2 minutes.
Step 5: Add the tempering to the curd rice and mix well.
Step 6: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 7: Chill in the refrigerator for 30 minutes before serving.
Step 8: Serve cold with pickle or papad.

name: Pudina Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook basmati rice until fully done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat oil in a pan and sauté sliced onions until translucent. Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies, and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add mint leaves and sauté for 2-3 minutes until wilted.
Step 4: Add turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Step 5: Add the cooked rice to the pan and gently mix to combine with the mint mixture.
Step 6: Cook on low heat for 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with raita or pickle.

name: Vegetable Pulao
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and sauté sliced onions until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add mixed vegetables and sauté for 3-4 minutes until slightly tender.
Step 4: Add turmeric, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well.
Step 5: Add the soaked rice and water (1:2 ratio). Stir gently.
Step 6: Cover the pan with a tight lid and cook on low heat until the rice is fully cooked.
Step 7: Garnish with mint and coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with raita or pickle.

name: Jeera Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook basmati rice until fully done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and add cumin seeds. Let them splutter.
Step 3: Add cashews and sauté until golden.
Step 4: Add the cooked rice and gently mix to combine with the cumin and cashews.
Step 5: Add salt to taste and mix well.
Step 6: Cook on low heat for 2-3 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with dal or curry.

name: Dal Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook rice and toor dal together until soft and set aside.
Step 2: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter.
Step 3: Add curry leaves and green chilies. Sauté for 1-2 minutes.
Step 4: Add turmeric powder and mix well.
Step 5: Add the cooked rice and dal mixture to the pan and mix well.
Step 6: Cook on low heat for 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with pickle or papad.

name: Bisibele Bath
preparation: Step 1: Cook rice and toor dal together until soft and set aside.
Step 2: Soak tamarind in water and extract the juice.
Step 3: Heat ghee in a pan and add mixed vegetables. Sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Step 4: Add tamarind juice, bisibele bath powder, jaggery, and salt. Cook until vegetables are tender.
Step 5: Add the cooked rice and dal mixture to the pan and mix well.
Step 6: Cook on low heat for 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 7: Garnish with grated coconut and fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with papad or potato chips.

name: Veg Noodles
preparation: Step 1: Boil noodles until al dente, drain, and set aside.
Step 2: Heat oil in a wok or pan and sauté finely chopped garlic until fragrant.
Step 3: Add sliced onions and cook until translucent.
Step 4: Add mixed vegetables and stir-fry on high heat for 3-4 minutes.
Step 5: Add soy sauce, vinegar, salt, and pepper. Mix well.
Step 6: Add the boiled noodles and toss gently to combine with the vegetables.
Step 7: Garnish with chopped spring onions.
Step 8: Serve hot with chili sauce or ketchup.

name: Kothu Parotta (Veg)
preparation: Step 1: Shred parottas into small pieces and set aside.
Step 2: Heat oil in a pan and sauté sliced onions until golden brown.
Step 3: Add chopped tomatoes and green chilies. Cook until tomatoes turn soft.
Step 4: Add turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well.
Step 5: Add the shredded parotta pieces and mix well with the masala.
Step 6: Cook on low heat for 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with raita or salna.

name: Mushroom Fried Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook basmati rice until fully done, cool it, and set aside.
Step 2: Heat oil in a wok or pan and sauté finely chopped garlic until fragrant.
Step 3: Add sliced onions and cook until translucent.
Step 4: Add sliced mushrooms and stir-fry on high heat for 3-4 minutes.
Step 5: Add soy sauce, vinegar, salt, and pepper. Mix well.
Step 6: Add the cooked rice and toss gently to combine with the mushrooms.
Step 7: Garnish with chopped spring onions.
Step 8: Serve hot with manchurian or chili sauce.

name: Brinjal Biryani
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Cook the rice until 70% done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and sauté sliced onions until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy.
Step 4: Add sliced brinjal and cook until tender.
Step 5: Add yogurt, turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well and cook for 5 minutes.
Step 6: Layer the partially cooked rice over the brinjal mixture. Sprinkle mint and coriander leaves on top.
Step 7: Cover the pan with a tight lid and cook on low heat for 15-20 minutes (dum cooking).
Step 8: Gently mix the biryani before serving. Serve hot with raita or salan.

name: Peas Pulao
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and sauté sliced onions until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add green peas and sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Step 4: Add turmeric, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well.
Step 5: Add the soaked rice and water (1:2 ratio). Stir gently.
Step 6: Cover the pan with a tight lid and cook on low heat until the rice is fully cooked.
Step 7: Garnish with mint and coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with raita or pickle.

name: Cashew Pulao
preparation: Step 1: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and sauté sliced onions until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until fragrant.
Step 3: Add cashews and sauté until golden.
Step 4: Add turmeric, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well.
Step 5: Add the soaked rice and water (1:2 ratio). Stir gently.
Step 6: Cover the pan with a tight lid and cook on low heat until the rice is fully cooked.
Step 7: Garnish with mint and coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with raita or pickle.

name: Podi Rice
preparation: Step 1: Cook rice until fully done and set aside.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a pan and add curry leaves. Sauté for 1-2 minutes.
Step 3: Add idli podi and mix well.
Step 4: Add the cooked rice and gently mix to combine with the podi mixture.
Step 5: Add salt to taste and mix well.
Step 6: Cook on low heat for 2-3 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 8: Serve hot with curd or pickle.

name: Thayir Semiya
preparation: Step 1: Cook vermicelli until soft, drain, and set aside to cool.
Step 2: Mix curd with the cooled vermicelli and add salt to taste.
Step 3: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter.
Step 4: Add curry leaves, green chilies, and grated ginger. Sauté for 1-2 minutes.
Step 5: Add the tempering to the curd vermicelli and mix well.
Step 6: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Step 7: Chill in the refrigerator for 30 minutes before serving.
Step 8: Serve cold with pickle or papad.

name: Chapati with Kurma
preparation: Step 1: Mix whole wheat flour, water, and salt to make a soft dough. Let it rest for 15 minutes.
Step 2: Divide the dough into small balls and roll them into thin circles using a rolling pin.
Step 3: Cook the chapatis on a hot tawa until both sides are golden brown.
Step 4: For the kurma, sauté onions, tomatoes, and spices in oil until fragrant.
Step 5: Add chopped vegetables and cook until tender.
Step 6: Grind coconut with spices to make a paste and add it to the vegetables.
Step 7: Simmer the kurma for 10 minutes until the flavors blend.
Step 8: Serve hot chapatis with the vegetable kurma.

name: Parotta with Salna
preparation: Step 1: Knead maida, water, and oil into a soft dough. Rest for 30 minutes.
Step 2: Divide the dough into small balls and roll them into thin sheets.
Step 3: Fold the sheets into layers and roll them into spirals.
Step 4: Cook the parottas on a hot tawa with oil until crispy.
Step 5: For the salna, sauté onions, tomatoes, and spices in oil.
Step 6: Add coconut paste and water to make a gravy.
Step 7: Simmer the salna for 10 minutes until thick.
Step 8: Serve hot parottas with spicy salna.

name: Dosa with Chutney & Sambar
preparation: Step 1: Soak rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds for 6 hours. Grind into a smooth batter and ferment overnight.
Step 2: Spread the batter on a hot tawa to make thin dosas. Cook until crispy.
Step 3: For coconut chutney, grind coconut, chana dal, and green chilies with water.
Step 4: Temper the chutney with mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Step 5: For sambar, cook vegetables with tamarind, sambar powder, and water.
Step 6: Add cooked toor dal to the vegetables and simmer.
Step 7: Temper the sambar with mustard seeds, fenugreek, and asafoetida.
Step 8: Serve hot dosas with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Set Dosa with Vegetable Kurma
preparation: Step 1: Soak rice, urad dal, and poha for 6 hours. Grind into a smooth batter and ferment overnight.
Step 2: Pour ladles of batter on a hot tawa to make thick, soft dosas.
Step 3: For the kurma, sauté onions, tomatoes, and spices in oil.
Step 4: Add chopped vegetables and cook until tender.
Step 5: Grind coconut with spices to make a paste and add it to the vegetables.
Step 6: Simmer the kurma for 10 minutes until the flavors blend.
Step 7: Cook the set dosas until golden brown on both sides.
Step 8: Serve hot set dosas with vegetable kurma.

name: Idiyappam with Coconut Milk
preparation: Step 1: Boil water with salt and mix it with rice flour to make a soft dough.
Step 2: Press the dough through an idiyappam maker to form noodles.
Step 3: Steam the idiyappam in a steamer for 10 minutes.
Step 4: Heat coconut milk with sugar until warm.
Step 5: Fluff the steamed idiyappam with a fork.
Step 6: Pour the sweetened coconut milk over the idiyappam.
Step 7: Serve warm as a comforting dinner.
Step 8: Optionally, add a pinch of cardamom for extra flavor.

name: Kothu Parotta (Veg)
preparation: Step 1: Shred leftover parottas into small pieces.
Step 2: Sauté onions, tomatoes, and spices in oil until fragrant.
Step 3: Add chopped vegetables and cook until tender.
Step 4: Add the shredded parotta pieces and mix well.
Step 5: Cook on high heat, tossing continuously for 5 minutes.
Step 6: Add a splash of water if needed to prevent sticking.
Step 7: Garnish with coriander leaves and serve hot.
Step 8: Serve with raita or chutney for extra flavor.

name: Adai with Avial
preparation: Step 1: Soak rice and dals for 6 hours. Grind into a coarse batter.
Step 2: Add chopped onions, curry leaves, and spices to the batter.
Step 3: Spread the batter on a hot tawa to make thick adais.
Step 4: Cook until golden brown on both sides.
Step 5: For avial, cook mixed vegetables with curd and coconut paste.
Step 6: Add curry leaves and coconut oil for flavor.
Step 7: Simmer the avial until the vegetables are tender.
Step 8: Serve hot adai with avial.

name: Uthappam with Kara Chutney
preparation: Step 1: Use fermented dosa batter to make uthappam.
Step 2: Pour ladles of batter on a hot tawa and spread thickly.
Step 3: Top with chopped onions, tomatoes, and green chilies.
Step 4: Cook until the base is crispy and the top is cooked.
Step 5: For kara chutney, grind coconut, roasted chana dal, and red chilies.
Step 6: Temper the chutney with mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Step 7: Serve hot uthappam with spicy kara chutney.
Step 8: Optionally, add grated carrot or capsicum as toppings.

name: Vella Paniyaram with Coconut Chutney
preparation: Step 1: Mix rice flour, jaggery syrup, and cardamom powder to make a batter.
Step 2: Heat a paniyaram pan and grease the molds with oil.
Step 3: Pour the batter into the molds and cook on medium heat.
Step 4: Flip the paniyaram to cook evenly on both sides.
Step 5: For coconut chutney, grind coconut, urad dal, and green chilies.
Step 6: Temper the chutney with mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Step 7: Serve hot vella paniyaram with coconut chutney.
Step 8: Optionally, add grated coconut to the paniyaram batter.

name: Masala Dosa
preparation: Step 1: Use fermented dosa batter to make thin dosas.
Step 2: Spread the batter on a hot tawa and cook until crispy.
Step 3: For the masala, sauté onions, mustard seeds, and curry leaves.
Step 4: Add boiled and mashed potatoes with turmeric and salt.
Step 5: Cook the masala until well combined.
Step 6: Place a portion of the masala on the dosa and fold it.
Step 7: Serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.
Step 8: Optionally, add grated carrot or beetroot to the masala.

name: Ragi Dosa with Tomato Chutney
preparation: Step 1: Mix ragi flour, rice flour, and urad dal batter to make a smooth mixture.
Step 2: Spread the batter on a hot tawa to make thin dosas.
Step 3: Cook until crispy on both sides.
Step 4: For tomato chutney, sauté tomatoes, onions, and spices.
Step 5: Grind the mixture into a smooth chutney.
Step 6: Temper the chutney with mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Step 7: Serve hot ragi dosa with tangy tomato chutney.
Step 8: Optionally, add garlic or ginger to the chutney.

name: Vegetable Kuzhi Paniyaram
preparation: Step 1: Use fermented dosa batter to make kuzhi paniyaram.
Step 2: Add chopped vegetables and onions to the batter.
Step 3: Heat a paniyaram pan and grease the molds with oil.
Step 4: Pour the batter into the molds and cook on medium heat.
Step 5: Flip the paniyaram to cook evenly on both sides.
Step 6: Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.
Step 7: Optionally, add grated carrot or capsicum to the batter.
Step 8: Garnish with coriander leaves before serving.

name: Thavala Vadai
preparation: Step 1: Soak lentils for 4 hours and grind into a coarse batter.
Step 2: Add rice flour, chopped onions, and green chilies to the batter.
Step 3: Shape the batter into small vadas using your hands.
Step 4: Heat oil in a pan and deep-fry the vadas until golden brown.
Step 5: Drain excess oil on a paper towel.
Step 6: Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.
Step 7: Optionally, add curry leaves or grated ginger to the batter.
Step 8: Garnish with chopped coriander leaves before serving.

name: Kambu Dosai with Kara Chutney
preparation: Step 1: Soak pearl millet, rice, and urad dal for 6 hours. Grind into a smooth batter.
Step 2: Ferment the batter overnight.
Step 3: Spread the batter on a hot tawa to make thin dosas.
Step 4: Cook until crispy on both sides.
Step 5: For kara chutney, grind coconut, roasted chana dal, and red chilies.
Step 6: Temper the chutney with mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Step 7: Serve hot kambu dosai with spicy kara chutney.
Step 8: Optionally, add chopped onions or green chilies to the dosa batter.
